Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project to Invert the Classroom in Fish and Wildlife Science Disciplines: Enhancing experiential learning opportunities across the curriculum.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support for junior faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) who are starting to build a research program, as well as for mid-career faculty who need to re-direct and re-build a research program. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at the researcher's home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences.

The research initiation project from Alabama A&M University (AAMU) will overhaul undergraduate student instruction in six existing fish and wildlife courses that compose a concentration area in an accredited forestry program at a historically black university to improve performance on student learning outcomes. Course content will become substantial portions of learning modules to be designed and made available on Blackboard LearnÂ®, an on-line instructional support program. Class time will consist of performing quantitative and written assignments. Specific activities include making all lecture notes and assignments available on-line and developing, or expanding existing, quantitative homework assignments into lab experiments and field exercises requiring technically written research reports.

These activities constitute an evaluation of the merits of a relatively new teaching pedagogy (inverting the classroom) designed to increase performance on existing student learning outcomes related to achievement of quantitative and communication competencies. Experiential learning has the potential to improve quantitative problem solving and communication competencies to increase undergraduate success in wildlife biology.

The activities will likely improve student learning outcomes in existing academic programs (minors) in Fisheries and Wildlife Biology disciplines where minority participation is extremely low (less than 1%). As an NSF Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) jurisdiction, this project broadens participation geographically as well as through efforts to attract and retain underrepresented minority students in biological and ecological sciences. The project leverages previous investments in course development and improvement from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA). Project outcomes will be disseminated broadly.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fish & wildlife resources are owned by the public. A majority of society wishes to see its natural resources managed for conservation and wise use. The training of scientists and managers to promote protection of fish and wildlife and their habitats occurs primarily in the nation's land grant colleges, including Albama A&M University (AAMU). AAMU is a Historically Black College or University (HBCU) with a fish and wildlife training program attached to its professionally-accredited forestry program. AAMU is the first and still only HBCU to be professionally accredited by the Society of American Foresters. Thus, the program strives for excellence in training tomorrow's stewards the nation's fish and wildlife resources. The outcomes of our program, aided mightily by the support of this NSF grant, are professionally trained women and minoriies in critical scientific disciplines.

Students at AAMU were engaged in more hands-on training in their fish and wildlife courses that were overhauled from traditional lecture courses. Instead the courses were more like field and laboratory exercises that directly involved the students in using the course information that was provided on-line to collect original data on actual animals and their habitats. The students then analyzed the data in class and prepared a written report that was structured like a scientific article that would be used to share their findings with the scientific community and the public. Assessment of their learning outcomes showed substantial improvement in both their writing and mathematical skills after the class format was overhauled. Also, their appreciation for, and understanding of, the biology and ecology of animal diets, population growth, species diversity, home range and habitat suitability was evident in their motivation to study for quizzes and exams in the course to test their knowledge.

Another way that students were given opportunities to use what they had learned in the curriculum was the undergraduate research field project. Students performed a variety of fish and wildlife research outside of class, usually over the summer in a nearby national forest. Student projects included diet analysis of river otters, building and maintaining an aquaculture-aquaponics system in the campus greenhouse, wildlife inventory for rare species of small mammals including bats, capture and measurement of stream fishes and their habitats, as well as investigating the impact of prescribed burning on wild hog use of forests. Students completed their data collection and analysis, prepared a presentation and many shared their presentations with other scientists at wildlife conferences or campus conference to show results in scientific, technical, engineering and math (STEM) fields. Two studenst won top prizes in the competition for their presentations.

Students, staff and faculty also particpated in meetings with the public and outreach to children in local schools to share their results and increase interest in the science of fish and wildlife resources. These venues were an opportunity for students to improve their public speaking skills at citizen group meetings about national forest management or at several campus events such as our annual "forestry fair". Our students enjoyed interacting with these groups to spread the message of wildlife conservation and motivate students to study in scientific disciplines. Most of our students are minorities and women, thus demonstrating that these resources belong to all US citizens and motivating youth from diverse backgrounds to pursue scientific careers.
